Love it. Amazing Medieval architecture in Paris, close to the metro line 7. Absolutely worth an exterior visit.
On July 28th, 1830. One of the cannonballs hit the hotel dr send and remains fixed in the mansion. A unusual memorial to the French Revolution.
Besides the magnificent library, there are historical exhibits that you won't find anywhere else.

Only saw a very small part of their gallery.  I found their small collection of wood samples from 1957 interesting to see, to industrial wood flooring having such a depth of design and development to wood flooring.  There's also a library for access.  Photography permitted in the gallery without flash.  No photography permitted in the library.  Free entry.
BEAUTIFUL BUILDING ! My wife and I stopped by this historic hotel during our guided bike tour while we were on vacation in Paris. NICE AREA ! Visited on

One of my favorite places. I would happily return. Look for the Revolutionary cannonball still lodged in its outer wall! Check to see if there's an exhibit next to the Forney library (all in the same building). Then go to the Village de St. Paul nearby and look for the remains of a 13th century wall!
Amazing architecture
beautiful view and garden
Nice to see this original canonball from the second french revolution
Beautiful renaissance garden hidden in the Marais
A cannonball from 1830 is stuck in the facade.
Seasonal flowers

Magnificent flower garden in a beautiful architectural setting. This garden perfectly illustrates the art of so-called French gardens. Trimmed box hedges create flowerbeds with geometric shapes. Throughout the seasons, plants and flowers flourish there, magnifying the facade of the H√¥tel de Sens. A rare testimony to medieval civil architecture in Paris, the hotel was built from 1475 to 1519, on the order of Tristan de Salazar, archbishop of Sens. He hosted for a few months Marguerite de Valois (1553-1615), ‚ÄúQueen Margot‚Äù, first wife of King Henri IV (1553-1610). The cardinal archbishops left him in 1622. Sold as national property during the Revolution, it was successively a laundry, a canning factory and the depot of a glassworks, among others. The City of Paris bought it in 1911 and restored it from 1929 to 1961. It has since housed the Forney library, devoted to decorative arts, crafts, techniques, fine arts and graphic arts.

A wonderful and unreal place. You feel like you have been transported to Gothic Touraine. No wonder, as the builder came from Amboise. The inner courtyard is worth seeing, as are the outer towers. With them you could see all the streets. Behind it is a garden √† la French where you can sit down quietly.
Very beautiful building. You can enter the courtyard and the hall which leads to the library. On the other hand, you can only visit this place during heritage days.

Magnificent place that I visited during the heritage days and that I highly recommend. I was lucky enough to have a guide who explained the whole history of the place to us and who was really interesting. Don't forget to take a walk in the garden behind which is public.

Rush into this garden! To escape the noise of the city, immerse yourself in the novel that keeps you going, or take a walk with a loved one.  On a small surface area, this space offers you a perfect example of an extraordinarily colorful French garden.  If the geometry, the flowerbeds, and the little carefully trimmed box hedges horrify you, go ahead anyway!  Because at the end of summer, the underlying geometry disappears under vaporous clouds of flowers in bright colors.  It‚Äôs a parade that you‚Äôre attending. Dahlias, Japanese anemones and marsh sages set themselves a challenge. It‚Äôs the one that will point closest to the clouds.  The local gardeners took part in this insane race towards the blue by setting up bamboo tripods, which the ipomeas decided to climb at full speed.  Let yourself be exhilarated by this crazy ride which will transport you elsewhere... perhaps to the time of medieval Paris, if you continue the walk by discovering the H√¥tel de Sens which overlooks the garden, and which once housed the famous Queen Margot.  Great discovery for you!
Not a friendly welcome, not a glance. I couldn't go back, just to take a look at the library.
A magnificent place, this hotel in Sens, with a remarkable exhibition on Jeanne Malivel.  Free exhibition, it must be emphasized... very warm welcome
Small gardens with lots of tulips in April. Free access.

The only urban palace in all of Paris that dates back to the Gothic period. It was built between 1475 and 1507 and served as a residence for the archbishops of Sens. It was later converted into a post office, then the headquarters of various craft businesses and since 1916 it has belonged to the city of Paris. Today you will find a specialist library for applied arts there.
Current exhibition on advertising in the 1920s in Paris, with special mention for the 1924 Olympic Games. Beautiful posters to admire
Magnificent French garden, located in front of the hotel of the archbishops of Sens. It is very flowery this month of May, take advantage of it! I highly recommend
Beautiful French garden where it is pleasant to take a break during visits to the marsh or Saint Louis Island. Just a few steps from the right bank quays and quieter
A real little gem of Paris... you are transported back in time...
To see and explore. The garden behind is also very pleasant
Disappointed with the Forney library. Much less attractive than the various sites of the BNF or the MAZARINE library. The H√¥tel de Sens has been very well restored.
Very particular building. Worth a visit if you are in the area
I lived right next door! very beautiful monument! and very beautiful neighborhood
A small, quiet garden, well planted with trees in a green setting. The only downside is the street which is crowded with cars so we are sometimes entitled to a few honks in our ears.
Beautiful 15th century architecture to see very well located Pleasant environment don't forget the St Antoine church which is very close where Bourvil plundered the trunks.
A library with beautiful exhibitions, and a very beautiful garden
I just walked past it, very beautiful place, remarkably restored! To have !

Even if the H√¥tel de Sens, with its very pretty architecture, is currently closed... its garden is accessible by entering a little far from the street...! Very stylized and refined garden, beautifully crafted where time seems to have been turned back to offer us this beautiful French garden.... Lots of sun and not a lot of shade: so for sun lovers you will understand!....

A late medieval style hotel, a beautiful garden, a library upstairs, a free exhibition space which deserves to be better known, talking about regional artists who are themselves little known to the general public. Between walks, architectural history and the arts.
It's a quiet park where you can relax.

Former hotel of the bishops of Sens, today municipal library. Exceptional Gothic architecture, note its turrets; too bad that over the centuries it has lost the majority of its ornamentation through restorations. Beautifully flowered garden. The interior architecture is also worth the detour. This library specializes in fine arts: architecture, drawing, painting and photography, etc. with a rich fund. The place also offers exhibitions.
